SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient has been feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for approximately five weeks. He has been involved in home renovations and has had some dietary struggles due to the construction in his kitchen. He has been compliant with his medications and has been monitoring his blood pressure at home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Endorses slight cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%. Mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical examination and chest x-ray findings.
• Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if there is weight gain or shortness of breath.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after test results are received.

Chief Complaint:

Right knee pain.

History of Present Illness:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has tried applying ice and taking Ibuprofen, but it does not help. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is taking digoxin.

Physical Examination:

Knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

Results:

X-rays of the right knee show no obvious signs of acute fracture. Mild effusion noted.

Impression:

Right knee medial meniscus sprain/strain.

Plan:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended a knee brace and crutches for the next couple of days. She will follow up with me in about a week, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin, 800 mg to take every 6 hours with food for two weeks. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain. The patient reports that he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. He heard a pop and experienced pain in his lower back. This occurred on Saturday morning, and the patient has had stiffness and pain since then. The patient has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat for pain relief, but they have not been very effective. The patient reports some tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon, which has since resolved. The patient finds relief when lying on his right side.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Endocrine: Diabetes type 2.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Back X-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fractures noted.

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient experienced pain after lifting heavy boxes too quickly.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and abnormal lab finding.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph Johnson is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam.

The patient has been managing his depression with Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been struggling with hypertension but is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week, occasionally forgetting on weekends. He had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and has not had any issues with shortness of breath except during high pollen season.

The patient endorses shortness of breath with exertion while running 4-5 miles a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath at rest.
• Neurological: Denies seizures, dizziness.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-controlled with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ralph Johnson is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.

Prior lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has no concerning symptoms or findings related to his prior lobectomy.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Norvasc, despite occasional missed doses on weekends.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the systolic ejection murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc at the current dosage.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over a mogul, her finger got caught and bent backwards. This happened on Sunday. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for the pain, but it has not provided significant relief. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also mentions a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She had an appendectomy at the age of 18.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right finger pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right index finger: No fractures, good alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today with right finger pain after a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger, with pain during flexion. The x-ray shows no fractures.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe an aluminum foam splint and Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to return if the pain does not improve within a week.

Constipation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently taking Miralax for constipation.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Miralax as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 1 week if the pain does not improve.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also mentions worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Fatigue, feverish with chills.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Anxiety and depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Iron deficiency anemia
• Hysterectomy in 1996

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily
• Over-the-counter vitamin B12

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezing.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of anemia since the age of 13 and has been taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12 supplements. She reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Referral: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Anxiety and depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports worsening anxiety and depression.
• Medical Treatment: Monitor and address during follow-up appointments.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Joint pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrew Perez is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for a kidney transplant, hypothyroidism, and arthritis. He presents today with complaints of joint pain in both knees after moving boxes up and down the basement stairs over the weekend. The pain has been persistent and not relieved by Tylenol or icing. The patient denies any fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Kidney transplant, hypothyroidism, arthritis.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Musculoskeletal: Edema and erythema of the right knee with pain to palpation. Range of motion is decreased. Left knee exam is normal.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee is unremarkable. Good bony alignment. No acute fractures.

Labs: Within normal limits. White blood cell count is within normal limits. Kidney function is normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Andrew Perez is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for a kidney transplant, hypothyroidism, and arthritis. He presents today with complaints of joint pain.

Arthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports increased joint pain in his bilateral knees over the past weekend. Given that his right knee x-ray was unremarkable, I believe this is an acute exacerbation of his arthritis.
• Additional Testing: We will order an autoimmune panel for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours as needed.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to rest his knees. If his symptoms persist, we can consider further imaging and possibly a referral to physical therapy.

Hypothyroidism.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Synthroid and is asymptomatic at this time.
• Additional Testing: We will order a thyroid panel.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Synthroid.

Status post renal transplant.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well and has been compliant with his immunosuppressive medications. On recent labs, his white blood cell count was within a normal limits and his kidney function is stable.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for prior discectomy, who presents with back pain. The patient reports feeling something in the lower right side of his back while pushing a refrigerator through another room approximately 5 days ago. He has been taking ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain relief. He denies numbness and tingling in his legs, and any problems with his bladder or bowels.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower right side back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation to the right lumbar spine and the paraspinal muscles. Decreased flexion and extension of the back. Positive straight leg raise on the right. Strength is good bilaterally in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fractures were noted.

Labs: Within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for prior discectomy, who presents with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: He reports right-sided low back pain after moving a refrigerator approximately 5 days ago. X-ray of his lumbar spine is unremarkable. I do not believe this is related to his previous discectomy.
• Additional Testing: We will order a MRI of the lumbar spine for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily, as well as Ultram 50 mg every 4 hours as needed.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer him to physical therapy to be started after we get his MRI results back.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to discontinue the use of ibuprofen, but he may continue using Tylenol if he wishes.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed or if symptoms recur.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain and possible kidney issues related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents with her mother for evaluation of possible kidney issues related to her syndrome. The patient has a history of reflux and has been taken off cow's milk. She is currently on a diet of pea protein milk, water, and occasionally water with a little bit of juice. She has been receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. Speech therapy is scheduled to start within the next couple of weeks.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has been having back pain and is concerned about possible kidney issues related to her syndrome. She also reports that Katherine has been having difficulty with eating and regulating her temperature. Katherine has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Endorses reflux and difficulty eating.
• Genitourinary: No issues reported.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain and difficulty walking.
• Neurological: Developmental delays related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting with back pain and possible kidney issues related to her syndrome. We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a female patient, reports injuring her right wrist after slipping while carrying a laundry basket down the stairs. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has been experiencing severe pain (9/10) and swelling in the wrist. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal improvement.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

No prior injuries to the right arm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Right Wrist:
- Obvious swelling and bruising
- Tenderness on palpation
- Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction
- Able to make a fist, but not tightly
- Bony crepitus present

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 140/70 mmHg
Heart Rate: 80 bpm
Temperature: 97.2 degrees F
Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/min

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

1. Provide a brace for the right wrist.
2. Schedule surgery for the right wrist fracture.
3. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Refer to physical therapy post-surgery for rehabilitation.
5. Follow up in 1 month to assess progress and discuss vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1 month for a progress assessment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 36-year-old male presenting with right knee pain after slipping and falling while working on his property. The injury occurred one week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain and swelling since. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief. He rates his pain as 4/10 when moving his knee. He has a past medical history of hypertension.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Patient is in no apparent distress.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN

1. For the right knee MCL strain:
   - Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling.
   - Provide a knee brace for support.
   - Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
   - Encourage elevation and rest for the affected leg.

2. For hypertension:
   - Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up as needed for knee pain and hypertension management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne Johnson is a 57-year-old male who presents today with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. The patient is unsure of any specific injury that may have caused the pain but has been active and working on renovating his basement. The pain is constant and worsens when trying to reach for objects or put pressure on the shoulder. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every 6-8 hours, which provides some relief but does not eliminate the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in the arm or hand.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left shoulder pain and limited range of motion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Limited active and passive range of motion in the left shoulder. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Vitals: Within normal limits.

RESULTS

X-ray left shoulder: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Wayne Johnson is a 57-year-old male who presents today with left shoulder pain.

Left shoulder pain - likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has limited range of motion and tenderness in the left shoulder, consistent with a rotator cuff injury.
• Additional Testing: Order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the injury.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and annual visit.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 27-year-old female who presents for her annual visit and reports occasional left knee pain. She describes the pain as occurring less than once a day when walking, causing her knee to feel like it is giving out. The patient denies any recent injury or trauma to the knee. She also reports struggling with depression and is currently taking Prozac 20 mg daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Left knee pain.
• Neurological: No numbness or tingling.
• Psychiatric: Depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Coronary artery bypass grafting at a young age due to congenital artery issue.
• Chronic back pain.
• Depression.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

• Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, and Hydrochlorothiazide for blood pressure management.
• Metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital signs: Temperature 98.2°F, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood pressure 122/70.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee without ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain: Likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension: Stable on current medications.
3. Diabetes mellitus: Monitoring and management.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and determine if adjustments to Metformin are needed.
4. Increase Prozac dosage from 20 mg to 40 mg daily for depression management.

The nurse will assist the patient in scheduling the echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time.

Today, Beverly reports minimal cough and sore throat. She has not experienced any shortness of breath, and her cough is mostly dry. She has been feeling more fatigued lately but has not experienced any nausea or vomiting. Beverly has been able to eat but not as much as she normally would. She has not had any issues with food getting stuck in her throat.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits.

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
2. Radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN

1. Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion and consider surgical removal of the tumor if it has shrunk sufficiently.
2. Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation related to radiation pneumonitis.
3. Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times daily) to alleviate painful swallowing and promote adequate food and fluid intake.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Return for next scheduled visit.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

The patient is a 58-year-old male who presents for evaluation of a low IgA level, as reported by his primary care physician. The patient has a history of frequent colds during the wintertime, which tend to linger. He denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has no known family history of immune deficiencies. The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Type 2 Diabetes

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:

Vitals: Stable, no fever.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS:

IgA level: Low, consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. IgA deficiency: The patient has a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without knowing they have it. The patient is advised to watch for any infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other immunodeficiencies. The patient is advised to inform healthcare providers of his IgA deficiency if he ever needs blood products.

2. Type 2 Diabetes: The patient is currently on metformin. He is advised to continue monitoring his blood sugar levels and maintain a healthy diet.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports developing right elbow pain over the past week, which he attributes to increased pottery and ceramics activities during the pandemic. The pain is located on the inside of the right elbow and sometimes radiates into the forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 in intensity and has been present for four days. The pain interferes with daily activities and keeps the patient awake at night. The patient has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics activities during the pandemic.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ibuprofen.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
The patient is in no apparent distress.

Musculoskeletal
Right elbow: Positive for pain to palpation with moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm. Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray Right Elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality observed.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow, likely due to overuse and potential damage to tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.

PLAN

1. Rest: The patient is advised to wear a sling while awake and avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks.
2. Ice: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

Wear a sling, apply ice to the elbow, take ibuprofen as directed, and avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. Follow up in one week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hypertension.
Abnormal liver enzymes.
Abnormal weight gain.
Acne vulgaris.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christine Hernandez is a 39-year-old female who presents today for evaluation and management of abnormal liver enzymes and hypothyroidism.

The patient has not started the new thyroid medicine, Unithroid, due to the cost of $75 and continues taking her previous thyroid medicine. She did not fill the prescription for Epiduo for her acne vulgaris due to the cost of $100. She tried filling both prescriptions at Walmart.

Mrs. Hernandez still presents with abnormal weight gain. She questioned if her oral contraceptive Microgestin, which was discontinued, could have been the cause. Additional symptoms included acne, hirsutism. She is attempting to modify her intake and plans to resume her gym membership in July as she will be on vacation. She inquired about the impact on weight loss of chromium, CLA, and amino acids.

The patient confirmed that she is taking her high dose Vitamin D as prescribed. She does suffer from constipation and she treats with MiraLAX.

She denies previous treatment for her acne vulgaris. She denies ever using clindamycin topical antibiotic. She reports having sensitive skin, developing rashes with various skin products.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypothyroidism.
Acne Vulgaris.
Vitamin D deficiency.
Abnormal weight gain.
Hirsutism.
Constipation.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Benzoyl Peroxide.
Clindamycin Gel applied topically.
Vitamin D 2000 IU daily.
Unithroid.
MiraLAX.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

RESULTS

Dexamethasone Suppression Test: Normal.

Salivary Cortisol Tests: 2 out of 3 were normal. Not consistent with Cushing’s Syndrome.

Hepatic Function Panel: ALT 128.
Lipid Panel: Total cholesterol 222 mg/dL, HDL 44 mg/dL, LDL 153 mg/dL, non-HDL 178 mg/dL.

FAI: Normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Hypothyroidism.
• Abnormal liver enzymes.
• Abnormal weight gain.
• Acne vulgaris
• Vitamin D deficiency.
• Hirsutism

PLAN

Hypothyroidism
The patient will again attempt to initiate Unithroid. I have printed out the prescription and a discount card, which should result in a reduced price. She will contact my office if she encounters additional issues.

Abnormal liver enzymes
We have seen improvement since the discontinuation of Microgestin. I recommended the spermicide Phexxi for alternative birth control. The patient will also continue working on weight loss, which should additionally improve her liver enzymes.

Abnormal weight gain
Cushing’s Syndrome has been ruled out. I reviewed the weight loss study with the patient, she will call within a month if she is interested in participating. I advised her to follow a low carbohydrate, low cholesterol, abstain from alcohol, and reduce fatty foods diet.

Acne vulgaris
Epiduo was not covered and too expensive. The patient will try benzoyl peroxide and Clindamycin separately to see if the price improves.

Vitamin D deficiency
The patient will complete the high dose vitamin D and then should start vitamin D 2000 IU per day to maintain her levels.

Hirsutism
Her androgen levels were normal.

INSTRUCTIONS

She will repeat all labs prior to her next visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain and kidney stone.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell Johnson is a 44-year-old male who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes, and when it comes, it is severe. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not provided relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father: kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with right-sided abdominal pain, burning sensation during urination, and dark-colored urine. The CT scan confirms the presence of a 0.5 cm kidney stone in the proximal right ureter.
• Medical Treatment: Recommend the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone when it passes.
• Additional Testing: Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
• Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If the patient is still having symptoms, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. He has had the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient noticed a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. He has been on antibiotics for six days, and the wound has turned black around the edges. He also reports cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The area is hot to touch.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1C is 6.7.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Integumentary: Endorses nonhealing foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage. Endorses red streak along the inside portion of the calf muscle.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses cramping in the calf muscle.
• Respiratory: Endorses coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing of tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

Results:

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer with signs of infection and possible cellulitis. No evidence of osteomyelitis on x-ray.
• Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound. Perform a culture of the wound.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current antibiotic therapy, consider changing or adding antibiotics based on culture results. Perform debridement in the office today. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely. Follow up in 7 days.

Diabetes management:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, with recent elevated blood sugars.
• Medical Treatment: Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist and continue monitoring blood sugars and maintaining an A1C below 7.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 7 days.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Lisinopril 20 mg once daily and Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever or chills.
Cardiovascular: Denies joint pain.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Temperature: 98.4 degrees F
Heart Rate: 67 bpm

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Right Knee Examination: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.

Skin
- Examination: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and inflammation over right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports good compliance with Lisinopril and blood pressure is well-controlled.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports blood sugars running in the 120s, indicating good control with Metformin.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
